Uses: The plant is having carminative,  stimulant and stomachic properties, and used for relieving nausea and flatulence. In stomach-ache and colicky diarrhoea the hot infusion is given. In  cases of rheumatism neuralgia, congestive headache, and tooth-ache it is applied externally.

Name: Mentha pulegium L.
Uses: The plant is having carminative,  stimulant and emmenagogue properties and is used in flatulence, nervous disorders, and gout, also used as an insect repellent.

Name: Mentha sativa L.
Uses: The plant contains an essential oil.

Name: Mentha spicata L.
Uses: The herb is employed as antispasmodic, carminative and stimulant. The sweetened infusion of the herb is prescribed for hysteria, infantile troubles and  vomiting during pregnancy.

Name: Mentha verticillata D.Don
Uses: Probably the source of Russian Spearmint Oil.

Name: Menyanthes trifoliata L.
Uses:
It is tonic, febrifuge, deobstruent and in large doses it is cathartic, emetic, and diaphoretic.
 It is used in treatment of  rheumatism, gout, dropsy, scurvy, and skin infections.

Name: Meriandra bengalensis Benth.
Uses:
It has carminative, astringent, and anti-septic properties and leaf infusion is used as a gargle
in  mouth wash in case of sore throat.

Name: Meriandra strobilifera Benth.
Uses: Leaf decoction used in treating ulcers and other skin infections.

Name: Merremia dissecta (Jacq.) Hallier f.
Uses: Seeds possess odour of oil of bitter almonds and used in the preparation of a liqueur.

Name: Merremia gangetica (L.) Cufod.
Uses: Used in rheumatism, neuralgia and also for cough.

Name: Merremia tridentata (L.) Hallier f.
Uses: Used in rheumatism, hemiplegia, piles, and urinary disorders.

Name: Merremia turpethum (L.) Shah & Bhatt
Uses: It has purgative action.

Name: Merremia umbellata (L.) Hallier f.
Uses: Plant employed in treatment of fistulae, pustules, and tumours. Leaves pounded and applied to burns,scalds, and sores. Seeds used in treatment of cutaneous diseases.

Name: Merremia vitifolia (Burm.f.) Hallier f.
Uses: Employed in treating stranguary and urethral discharge and has stomachic and diuretic properties.

Name: Mesua ferrea L.
Uses: Seeds used for skin troubles and as an embrocation in rheumatism. Flowers applied in cough, buds  used in dysentery. Bark combined with ginger applied as sudorific.

Name: Meyna laxiflora Robyns
Uses:
Dry fruits are used for treatment of  dysentery and boils. Powdered leaves are useful in treatment of
  diphtheria.

Name: Michelia champaca L.
Uses: Used as a diuretic in renal diseases. Flower from  oil used in cephalagia. Bark is used as stimulant, diuretic and febrifuge

Name: Michelia montana Blume
Uses: Bark useful as bitter tonic given in fevers.

Name: Michelia nilagirica Zenk.
Uses: Bark and leaves used in febrifuge.

Name: Microcos paniculata L.
Uses: Leaves used for wrapping cigars. Green loppings used as manure.

Name: Micromeria biflora (Buch.-Ham. ex D.Don) Benth.
Uses:
Yields 4 types of medicinal oils-camphorata, citrata, menthata,
and pulegata.

Name: Micromeria capitellata Benth.
Uses: The plant is having aromatic and carminative properties and is  good substitute for Mentha piperita L.

Name: Microrhychus nudicaulis Less.
Uses: It is used to cure fever by applying the leaves to the head of the children.

Name: Microsorum scolopendria (Burm.f.) Copel
Uses: The young fronds are used in chronic diarrhoea.

Name: Mikania cordata (Burm.f.) B.L.Rob.
Uses: Leaves are applied to itches and, in the form of poultice to wounds.

Name: Miliusa velutina (Dunal) Hook.f. & Thoms.
Uses: Bark has febrifuge property.

Name: Millettia extensa (Benth.) Baker
Uses:
Root vermifuge, pesticidal,
kills lice and ticks.

Name: Millettia pachycarpa Benth.
Collector: Reporter on Economic products to the Government of India
Uses: Roots used as fish poisining.

Name: Millettia piscidia Wight
Uses: Bark and flowers used as a fish-poison.

Name: Millettia racemosa Benth.
Uses: Leaves used as fodder. Roots employed as fish-poison; also used on sores of cattle to kill vermin.

Name: Millingtonia hortensis L.f.
Uses: Bark is antipyretic.

Name: Mimosa pudica L.
Uses: Leaves and Root is Juice is antiseptic, alterative and blood-purifier, piles and fistula; also is applied externally in fistulous sores, piles and scorpion sting.

Name: Mimosa rubicaulis Lam.
Uses: Leaves of the tree in infusion are prescribed for piles. Root's powdered is given for vomiting and the bruised leaves are applied to burns.

Name: Mimulus moschatus Douglas ex Lindl.
Collector: J.H. Sandberg, D.T. MacDougal and A.A. Heller
Uses: Has stimulant properties.

Name: Mimulus strictus Benth.
Uses: Used for treating menstrual disorders.

Name: Mimusops elengi L.
Uses: Bark and fruits used in diarrhoea and dysentery. Dried flowers used as snuff and pounded seed used in suppositories for constipation.

Name: Mitragyna parvifolia (Roxb.) Korth.
Uses: Bark and roots are used in colic and as febrifuge.

Name: Mitragyna rotundifolia (Roxb.) Kuntze
Uses: Bark is used in lowering  blood pressure and paralyses sympathetic nerve endings.

Name: Mollugo cerviana (L.) Ser.
Uses:
It is stomachic, aperient and antiseptic. Flowers and tender shoots are  diaphoretic and febrifuge. 
Roots are boiled in oil for treatment of gout and rheumatism.

Name: Mollugo nudicaulis Lam.
Uses: Pectoral is used in whooping cough. Leaves are applied to boils for suppuration.

Name: Mollugo pentaphylla L.
Uses: It is  stomachic, aperient, antiseptic, and emmenagogue and is  used  in poultices for sore legs.

Name: Monotropa uniflora L.
Uses: Roots are antispasmodic and act as nervine tonic.

Name: Morinda citrifolia L.
Uses: Leaf juice used in treatment of gout. Roots are cathartic and febrifugic in nature. Fruits extract is used in treatment of spongy gums, throat pain, dysentery, leucorrhoea and sapraemia.

Name: Morinda umbellata L.
Uses: Root and leaf decoction is used in treatment of diarrhoea.

Name: Moringa concanensis Nimmo
Uses: Pods used as fried  are used by diabetics and antiparalytic. Root juice used for nervous debility, asthma, enlarged liver and spleen, deep-seated inflammation and as diuretic in calculus infection.

Name: Moringa oleifera Lam.
Uses: Seeds antipyretic. Seed oil applied in rheumatism. All parts of the tree used in the treatment of ascites, venomous bites, rheumatism, and as cardiac and circulatory stimulants.

Name: Mormordica balsamina L.
Uses: The fruit is useful in curing wounds.

Name: Mormordica charantia L.
Uses: The root is used in ophthalmia and in prolapsus vaginae. The fruit is antipyretic, digestive, laxative, anthelmintic, appetiser, cures biliousness, kapha, blood diseases, anaemia, urinary discharges, asthma, ulcers, bronchitis. The juice is useful in treating cholera. The fruit is used to treat syphilis, troubles of spleen, rheumatism, ophthalmia.

Name: Mormordica cochinchinensis (Lour.) Spreng.
Uses:
The seeds are used for cough and chest complaints. The roots are used in treating rheumatism,
boils, abscesses and bubos. The seeds are useful in treatment of tumours, malignant ulcers and obstructions of liver and spleen.

Name: Mormordica dioica Roxb. ex Willd.
Uses:
The roots are used to cure head troubles, urinary calculi, as an errhine in jaundice. The leaves
are anthelmintic, cure tridosha, fever, consumption, asthma, bronchitis, hiccups, piles. The fruit is 
stomachic, laxative, cures vata, biliousness, asthma, leprosy,bronchitis, fever, tumours, tridosha, urinary
discharges, excessive salivation, troubles of heart. The root is useful in all kinds of poisoning including
snake bits and elephantiasis.

Name: Morus alba L.
Uses:
Fruits are used to treat sore throat,dyspepsia. Leaves are diaphoretic and roots 
are anthelmintic.Bark is purgative and vermifuge.

Name: Morus australis Poir.
Uses:
The root is anthelmintic,astringent. Decoction of root is used in treating internal parasite.
Bark is anthelmintic and purgative. Paste of the bark is used in treatment of gingivitis. Decoction of leaves are used as gargle in treating inflammation of vocal chords. It is used in treating scabies. Fruit has laxative properties and is used in biliousness. It is useful in treating fever. Fruit is diuretic, tonic, anthelmintic.

Name: Morus nigra L.
Uses:
Fruit is laxative. Bark is purgative and vermifuge. Infusion of leaves are used to drop 
blood sugar and arterial pressure.

Name: Moschosma polystachyum Benth.
Uses: Crushed leaves applied on sprains. The leaves decoction given as a sedative in epilepsy, palpitation of heart, neuralgia and convulsions

Name: Mucuna gigantea DC.
Uses:
Bark used in external applications for rheumatism. Powdered seeds given as a
purgative. Hairs on pods produce intense irritation and dermatitis.

Name: Mucuna monosperma DC. ex Wight
Uses: Seeds used in asthma, coughs, and tongue infections; external applications, prepared from seeds, sedative. Trichomes on pods are irritant and cause dermatitis.

Name: Mucuna nigricans (Lour.) Steud.
Uses: Watery sap from stem used for coughs and fevers. Trichomes on pods produce dermatitis.

Name: Mucuna pruriens (L.) DC.
Uses: Leaf applied to ulcers. Pod anthelmintic. Seed astringent, nervine tonic, local stimulant, used in impotence, spermatorrhoea, urinary troubles, leucorrhoea, traditionally used for male virility. Also used in depressive neurosis. Hair on fruit vermifuge, mild vesicant; used for diseases of liver and gallbladder.

Name: Murdannia scapiflora (Roxb.) Royle
Uses: Roots are used in snake-bite.

Name: Murraya koenigii (L.) Spreng.
Uses: Leaves used in diarrhoea, dysentery, vomiting. Root juice taken for relief from renal pain.

Name: Murraya paniculata (L.) Jacq.
Uses: Leaves used in diarrhoea and dysentery and cuts. Leaves along with root-bark used in curing coughs, rheumatism and hysteria.

Name: Musa paradisiaca L.
Uses: Fruits are used as vitamin, minerals etc.

Name: Mussaenda glabra Vahl
Uses:
Infusion of leaves is employed for treatment of cough. Decoction of the  roots is also taken for cough.
 Flowers  are diuretic and used in treatment of dropsy, asthma, and recurrent fevers.

Name: Mussaenda glabrata (Hook.f.) Hutch. ex Gamble
Uses:
Decoction of dried shoots are  given to children for relieve from coughs. Roots are demulcent and used 
for treatment of  white leprosy and eye troubles. Decoction of leaves are  used against intestinal worms.

Name: Myrica esculenta Buch.-Ham.
Uses: Bark is astringent, carminative, and antiseptic.Decoction is  considered useful in asthma, diarrhoea, fevers, chronic bronchitis, lung infections, and dysentery and diuresis. Bark is  chewed to relieve tooth-ache.

Name: Myricaria bracteata Royle
Uses: Bark used as a medicine to treat rheumatism.

Name: Myristica dactyloides Gaertn.
Uses: containing  stearic acid as the predominant saturated acid, and not myristic acid.

Name: Myristica fragrans Houtt.
Uses: Nutmeg and Mace are prescribed for inflammation of bladder and urinary passage. Nutmeg butter or fat obtained from nutmegs employed  as a mild external stimulant in ointments, hair lotions and plasters, also in cases of rheumatism, sprains, and paralysis it is very useful.

Name: Myristica malabarica Lam.
Uses: Seeds are applied externally in indolent ulcers. Crude-fat or Pundi oil is obtained from the seeds which is used in rheumatism.

Name: Myrsine africana L.
Uses: Fruit extract is used in treatment of tapeworm, ringworm, and is used as a laxative.

Name: Myrtus communis L.
Uses: Leaves used in treatment of cerebral infections, especially epilepsy, pulmonary disorders and dyspepsia and other diseases of stomach and liver. The decoction is  used as a mouthwash in apthae. Berries are carminative, and are given in diarrhoea and dysentery, rheumatism, and haemorrhage and internal ulceration. Myrtle Oil, obtained from leaves and flowers yield an essential oil, which is applied in rheumatism and infection of respiratory tract and bl

Name: Myxopyrum smilacifolium (Wall.) Blume
Uses:
Leaves are used in the treatment of asthma, cough, rheumatism, nervous complaints.
Leaves when boiled in oil is used for backache.

Name: Nannorhops ritchiena (Griff.) Wendl.
Uses: Young leaves are given in diarrhoea and dysentery. Also used in veterinary medicine.

Name: Nardostachys grandiflora DC.
Uses:
It is used to treat diseases of brain, digestive system, improves vision,paralysis, chorea, epilepsy
,convulsion of children,flatulence, colic, caries of teeth, emmenagogue.

Name: Naringi crenulata (Roxb.) Nicolson
Uses: Fruits have stomachic properties. Roots have purgative and sudorific properties.

Name: Nelumbo nucifera Gaertn.
Uses: Carpels are ground into flour which is considered more nutritive than cereals. Rhizomes yield a kind of nutritious arrowroot, which is  given to children in diarrhoea and dysentery. Carpels demulcent and nutritive.

Name: Neolitsea cassia (L.) Kosterm.
Uses: Roots and bark extract applied to eruptions.

Name: Olea dioica Roxb.
Uses: Barks yields febrifuge.

Name: Olea europaea L.
Uses: Oil has laxative, demulcent, and emollient properties.

Name: Olea ferruginea Royle
Uses: Leaf and bark is used in debility and act as febrifuge.

Name: Olea glandulifera Wall. ex G.Don
Uses: Bark and leaves are used as febrifuge.

Name: Onosma bracteatum Wall.
Uses:
Dried leaves constitute Unani drug Gaozoban. Gaozoban  is used as tonic, demulcent,
 diuretic and used as spasmolytic.

Name: Onosma hispidum Wall. ex G.Don
Uses: It is used in treating cutaneous diseases.

Name: Ophioglossum vulgatum L.
Uses: The plant is considered of having  antiseptic, detergent, styptic and vulnerary properties. The decoction of the plant is also used for angina.  On boils the warm decoction of rhizomes is applied.

Name: Ophiorrhiza mungos L.
Uses:
Roots are used as a tonic and are effective in cancer treatment. Decoction of roots, leaves and bark is 
employed as stomachic. Leaves are used for dressing ulcers.

Name: Opuntia coccinellifera Mill.
Uses:
Mucilaginous joints are  used in poultices for treatment of  articular rheumatism, inflammation,
 scalds, burns, skin diseases, ear-ache and tooth-ache.

Name: Opuntia nigricans Haw.
Uses:
Baked fruit is used in whooping cough. Mashed up stems are used as poultice
to allay inflammation and hot ones are applied to boils to hasten suppuration.
Pulp is used in ophthalmia.

Name: Oreocnide integrifolia Miq.
Uses: Medicines prepared from the plant is used in skin disease and etching.

Name: Origanum vulgare L.
Uses: An oil known as Origanum Oil which is obtained from the plant is having carminative, stomachic, diuretic, diaphoretic, and emmenagogue properties which is  used as a stimulant and tonic in diarrhoea and colic, also applied in chronic rheumatism, tooth-ache, and ear-ache. Because of its spasmolytic properties it is prescribed for whooping cough and bronchitis.

Name: Ormocarpum sennoides DC.
Uses: Roots tonic and stimulant, used for lumbago, they are rubbed in oil and applied in paralysis.

Name: Orobanche aegyptiaca Pers.
Uses: It is used in treating diarrhoea

Name: Oroxylum indicum (L.) Vent.
Uses: Root-bark is tonic and astringent. It is used in treating diarrhea and dysentery. It is diaphoretic and used in treating rheumatism. It is boiled in oil and used in otorrhoea. Seeds are purgative. Decoction of leaves are used in treating stomache, rheumatism. Leaves are applied externally on enlarged spleen.

Name: Orthosiphon grandiflorus Boldingh.
Uses: The leaves are containing of high percentage (0.7-0.8%) of potassium salts and thus it is useful as diuretic. Drug highly cumulative diuretic, most useful in nephrosis and severe cases of oedema (dropsy). In case if  kidney and bladder diseases including nephrocirrhosis and phosphaturia the infusion is used; aslo given in gout and rheumatism. The plant contains orthosiphonin and potassium salts which  helps in keeping uric acid and urate salts in solu

Name: Orthosiphon pallidus Royle ex Benth.
Uses: The plant is used in  urinary complain and fever.

Name: Osbeckia crinita Benth.
Uses: Decoction of root is used as a stomachic. Decoction  of dry leaves used for tooth-ache.

Name: Osbeckia nepalensis Hook.
Uses: Pounded flowers are applied to sores inthe mouth.

Name: Osmanthus fragrans Lour.
Uses: Flowers are used in medicinal preparations.

Name: Osmunda regalis L.
Uses: The roots of the plant is employed as mucilaginous, stimulant, styptic and tonic. For intestinal gripe and rheumatism an aqueous extract of the fern is used. It is considered of having antibacterial action. It is prescribed for dysentery, rickets, and muscular debility. The fronds of the plant form a constituent of diuretic drinks and is given for swellings. The tender shoots is also used in balms and healing plasters.

Name: Ougeinia oojeinensis (Roxb.) Hochr.
Uses:
Bark febrifuge, antidiarrhoeal,
spasmolytic.

Name: Ouratea angustifolia Baill. ex Laness.
Uses: Roots and leaf decoction has tonic and stomachic properties.

Name: Oxalis corniculata L.
Uses: Used in treating cold, cough and diarhhoea.

Name: Oxyria digyna (L.) Hill
Uses: Herb is antiscorbutic and refrigerant.

Name: Oxystelma secamone (L.) K.Schum.
Uses:
Herb is antiseptic, depurative, and galctagogue. Decoction is  used as gargle. Latex is  used as a vulnerary.
 Fresh roots are prescribed in treatment of  jaundice.

Name: Pachyrrhizus erosus (L.) Urban
Uses: The seeds powdered are used for insecticidal and piscicidal purposes. Leaves, roots, and pods also show insecticidal activity. The seeds are being employed as laxative vermifuge

Name: Paederia scandens (Lour.) Merr.
Uses: It has anti inflamatory properties and is used in treatment of tenesmus.

Name: Paeonia emodi Wall. ex Hook.f.
Uses: Fleshy roots useful in uterine related diseases, biliousness, dropsy and nervous infections. Seeds emetic and cathartic infusion of flowers given for diarrhoea. Roots contain an essential oil.

Name: Pajanelia longifolia (Willd.) K.Schum.
Uses: Root-bark is tonic and astringent. It is used in treating diarrhea and dysentery. It is diaphoretic and used in treating rheumatism. It is boiled in oil and used in otorrhoea. Seeds are purgative. Decoction of leaves are used in treating stomache, rheumatism. Leaves are applied externally on enlarged spleen.

Name: Panax pseudo-ginseng Wall.
Uses: It is used as an expectorant and antipyretic.

Name: Panicum antidotale Retz.
Uses: Used in infections of the throat and also used as an antidote in hydrophobia.

Name: Panicum incomtum Trin.
Uses: Roots considered in aphrodisiac, used and chewed with betel nuts.

Name: Panicum maximum Jacq.
Uses: It's rich with carotene and also contains vitamin C, B, and tocopherol.

Name: Papaver argemone L.
Uses: Infusion of the petals have sudorific property.

Name: Papaver dubium L.
Uses: Petals have sudorific property

Name: Papaver hybridum L.
Uses: The petals have diaphoratic property.

Name: Papaver nudicaule L.
Uses: Fiowers and capsules are mildly diaphoretic.

Name: Papaver orientale L.
Uses:
Petals have sudorific property, It contains thebaine during active growth, but at maturity isothebaine is mostly present, /jo-thebaine stimulates and later depresses central
nervous system.

Name: Papaver rhoeas L.
Uses: Petals used for coughs and hoarseness, also have sedative, anodyne, and sudorific properties. Fresh petals used in the preparation of galenicals; syrup or tincture used for colouring medicines and food materials,

Name: Papaver somniferum L.
Uses: Seeds useful in diarrhoea and dysentery and in compositions for skin care.infusion applied as a soothing application. Extract used as a sedative against irritating cough.

Name: Paracalyx scariosa (Roxb.) Ali
Uses: The leaves of the plant is used as antidote in snake bite and also as vermicidal. The root of the plant is employed in stomachache and  venereal diseases.

Name: Parameria polyneura Hook.f.
Uses: Bark decoction is used to treat wounds and also dysentery. Leaves and flowers infususion has emmenagogue properties.

Name: Paramignya angulata Kurz
Uses: It has diuretic properties.

Name: Paramignya monophylla Wight
Uses: Used in treating colic.

Name: Parsonsia helicandra Hook. & Arn.
Uses: Juice is used for treatment of insanity.

Name: Paspalum scrobiculatum L.
Uses: It's used for diabetics as a substitute for rice and stem juice is used to clear corneal opacity.

Name: Passiflora edulis Sims
Uses: The plant is used in itching, wounds, inflammation; the fruit is used in Asthma.

Name: Passiflora foetida L.
Uses: Fruits are emetic. Fruit decoction is used in asthma and biliousness. Decoction of leaves and roots is an emmenagogue and also used in hysteria.

Name: Pavetta crassicaulis Bremek.
Uses: Roots have tonic, purgative and diuretic properties and is used for treating visceral obstructions, urinary diseases, jaundice, and dropsy. Leaf Decoction is used for treating ulcerated nose and for haemorrhoids.

Name: Pavonia odorata Willd.
Uses: Roots are antipyretic, stomachic and refrigerent also used in dysentery and intestinal haemorrhage.

Name: Pavonia zeylanica (L.) Cav.
Uses: Useful as febrifuge and anthelmintic.

Name: Pedalium murex L.
Uses: Mucilaginous infusion formed is demulcent, diuretic and tonic properties and used in dysuria,gonorrhea and other diseases of urino-genital system. Decoction of roots are antibilious. Fruits are used an aphrodisiac and given as decoction for incontinence of urine, nocturnal emissions, spermatorthoea and impotence.

Name: Pedicularis pectinata Wall. ex Benth.
Uses: The leaves is having hemostatic properties and is utilized to stop spitting of blood. The plant is diuretic.

Name: Pedicularis siphonantha D.Don
Uses: The plant is having diuretic properties.

Name: Pedilanthus tithymaloides (L.) Poit.
Uses: The root of the plant is considered of having emetic properties. The latex of the plant is having emetic, irritant, and caustic properties and is utilized in venereal diseases. And for warts and leucoderma patches it is applied.

Name: Peganum harmala L.
Uses: The drug Harmal is obtained from dried seeds and used in treating asthma, hiccough, hysteria, rheumatism, dysmenorrhoea, and neuralgia

Name: Pelargonium graveolens L'Herit.
Uses: Yields an oil used in pharmaceutical preparations.

Name: Pellaea hastata (Thunb.) Prantl.
Uses: The fronds of the plant is smoked in asthma and cold in the head and chest. For anthelmintic the rhizome  are used.

Name: Pentapetes phoenicea L.
Uses: Mucilaginous capsule useful for bowel upset, decoction of it is applied as emollient. Roots antibilious useful for flatulence.

Name: Pentatropis spiralis (Forsk.) Decne
Uses: Roots are used in treatment of gonorrhoea.

Name: Pergularia daemia (Forsk.) Choiv.
Uses:
Plant is emetic, expectorant,anthelmintic. Decoction of leaves are used in asthma. Its juice is used in 
infantile diarrhoea.Combined with lime leaf juice is applied to rheumatic swellings.Pulped leaves are applied 
to carbuncles. Plant extract is applied for uterine and menstrual troubles and to facilitate parturition.

Name: Pericampylus glaucus (Lam.) Miers.
Uses: Infusion of leaves is used in asthma and fever.

Name: Perilepta auriculata (Nees) Bremek
Uses: Leaves applied as a febrifuge.

Name: Perilla frutescens (L.) Britton
Uses: The herb is having antispasmodic, diaphoretic and  sedative properties and is prescribed in cephalic and uterine troubles.

Name: Periploca aphylla Decne.
Uses: Juice is used to tumours and swellings. Decoction of bark is purgative.

Name: Peristrophe bicalyculata (Retz.) Nees
Uses: Essential oil obtained from it shows activity against tuberculosis.

Name: Peristrophe roxburghiana (Roem. & Schult.) Bremek.
Uses: Pounded leaves used in skin infections.

Name: Perovskia abrotanoides Kar.
Uses: It is employed for acidity of stomach and tenesmus.

Name: Petroselinum crispum (Mill.) Airy-Shaw
Uses: Dried leaves and roots are used as condiments. Fresh leaves are good source of iron, calcium, carotene and ascorbic acid. Herb are diuretic, ecbolic and emmenagogue and used in uterine troubles.

Name: Peucedanum dhana Buch.-Ham. ex C.B.Clarke
Uses: Carrot-like roots are used as a tonic and febrifuge.

Name: Peucedanum grande C.B.Clarke
Uses: Fruits are used as a condiment. They are carminative/ diuretic, imulant and tonic and also used in the form of infusion in gastric and intestinal troubles

Name: Peucedanum nagpurense Prain
Uses: Fistular stems are employed for flutes. Roots are used as a stomachic.

Name: Phaseolus adenanthus G.F.Meyer
Uses: A decoction is used in bowel complaints and stricture. The roots are used to stop excessive salivation.

Name: Phaseolus lunatus L.
Uses: Seeds used as a diet in fever.

Name: Phaseolus vulgaris L.
Uses:
Green pod shells used as a
diuretic especially in kidney and heart troubles.

Name: Phlogacanthus thyrsiflorus (Roxb.) Nees
Uses: Fruits and leaves has febrifuge properties.

Name: Phoenix dactylifera L.
Uses: Riped fruits used in respiratory diseases and fever.

Name: Phoenix pusilla Gaertn.
Uses:
Fruits are used in respiratory diseases and fever. Fresh sap cooling and laxative.
It's gum used in diarrhoea and urinary disorders.

Name: Phoenix sylvestris (L.) Roxb.
Uses: Roots used for toothache. Nira is a more nutritious and good source of vitamin B and vitamin C.

Name: Phyla nodiflora (L.) Greene
Uses: Herb has diuretic and febrifugic properties and employed in ischuria and stoppage of bowels.

Name: Phyllanthus acidus (L.) Skeels
Uses: The roots and seeds are having cathartic properties.

Name: Phyllanthus fraternus Webster
Uses: The plant possess astringent, deobstruent, diuretic, febrifuge and stomachic properties, and is utilized for stomach proplems for eg. diarrhoea, dysentery, dyspepsia and colicIt is also employed in dropsy and diseases of urino-genital system. In jaundice and                                    galactagogue fresh roots are used. On sores latex is applied.

Name: Phyllanthus maderaspatensis L.
Uses: The seeds of the plant is laxative, diuretic and carminative and contain a fatty oil. The leaves infusion is advice for headache.

Name: Phyllanthus urinaria L.
Uses: The leaves juice is adviced with coconut milk as an appetizer to children.

Name: Phyllanthus virgatus Forst.
Uses: The plant is having antiseptic properties. The leaves are employed for eye problems, itch, and gonorrhoea.  In mammary abscesses a preparation of roots are applied on it.

Name: Phyllochlamys taxoides Koord.
Uses: Smoke from the burning bark is inhaled for relief from cough.

Name: Physalis angulata L.
Uses: Fruit is used to treat ear ache. Fruit and seed is used to treat gastric trouble.

Name: Physalis minima L.
Uses: Fruits and leaves are tonic, diuretic, and purgative.

Name: Physalis peruviana L.
Uses: Leaves are used in treating abdominal disorders.

Name: Physochlaina praealta (Walp.) Hook.f.
Uses:
Leaves are  applied to boils.
 Seeds used to expel roundworms and  given as an emetic in bilious attack.

Name: Phytolacca acinosa Roxb.
Uses: Root is antiasthamatic, antibacterial, antidote, antifungal, antitussive, diuretic, expectorant, laxative and vermifuge. Root is used in treating urinary disorders, nephritis, oedema, abdominal distension. Externally, it is used to treat boils, carbuncles and sores.

Name: Picororhiza kurroa Royle ex Benth.
Uses: The drug Picrorhiza is obtained from the dried rhizomes and roots which is used as a substitute or adulterant of Indian Gentian-Gentiana kurroo Royle and is having bitter tonic almost as efficacious as gentian; also considered of having cholagogue and stomachic; in large doses it is cathartic  and in small doses it acts as laxative. It is beneficial in dropsy. The plant contains kutkin, picrorhizin,  and other compounds.

Name: Picrasma javanica Blume
Uses: It has febrifugic properties and is applied to sores.

Name: Picrasma quassioides (D.Don) Benn.
Uses: Barks and leaves have febrifugic properties.

Name: Picris hieracioides L.
Uses: Bitter leaves are used as febrifuge.

Name: Pilea microphylla (L.) Liebm.
Uses: Plants are used in gastric and intestinal troubles.infusion given as a diuretic. Crushed leaves applied to sores and bruises.

Name: Pimpinella anisum L.
Uses: Aniseed consists of dried fruits, expectorant, stimulant, carminative, diuretic, and diaphoretic, used in flatulent colic, in the preparation of asthma powders, and in veterinary medicine. Yields an essential oil, known as oil of Anise, which now replaces the fruits for medicinal and flavouring purposes.

Name: Pimpinella heyneana Wall.
Uses: Root is febrifuge.

Name: Pinanga dicksonii (Roxb.) Scheffer
Uses: Fruits, dried husk used in flatulence, obstructive diseases of stomach, and dropsy.

Name: Pinus gerardiana Wall. ex Lamb
Uses: Seeds are carminative and expectorant.

Name: Pinus roxburghii Sargent.
Uses:
It is expectorant and useful in chronic bronchitis, recommended for gangrene of lungs.   It is given as carminative in flatulent colic and to arrest minor haemorrhages in tooth-sockets 
and nose. It is used externally as rubefacient in rheumatic infections and deep seated inflammation especially for abdomen.

Name: Piper cubeba L.f.
Uses: The fruits of the plant is used for dysentery and also employed as aromatic stimulant, carminative, diuretic,  local irritant and sedative. In rheumatism, gonorrhoea, and broncheal troubles it is also used.

Name: Piper longum L.
Uses:
Roots and fruits are used for diseases of respiratory tract. It is analgesic for muscular
 pains and inflammation. It act as snuff in coma and drowsiness and used internally as carminative, as sedative in insomnia and epilepsy. It act as cholagogue in obstructions of bile duct and gall bladder and act as an emmenagogue and abortifacient.

Name: Piper retrofractum Vahl
Uses:
Fruits are carminative and used to treat digestive troubles, haemorrhoids and after 
parturition. Roots are chewed or brewed into decoction for use in colic and used for treating dyspepsia and gastralgia.

Name: Piper sarmentosum Roxb.
Uses: The roots of the plant which is known as Piplamul and fruits  are used for diseases of respiratory tract. It is also employed to counter-irritant and analgesic for muscular pains and inflammation. In cases of coma and drowsiness, and internally as a carminative it is used as snuff. In insomnia and epilepsy it is used as sedative. It is employed as cholagogue in obstructions of bile duct and gall-bladder and as an emmenagogue and  bortifacient.

Name: Piper sylvaticum Roxb.
Uses: Fruits are carminative.

Name: Piper trioicum Roxb.
Uses: It is rubefacient and is used as poultice.

Name: Piper wallichii (Miq.) Hand.-Mazz.
Uses: It Is used as uterine stimulant.

Name: Pisonia mitis L.
Uses: Fresh leaves are used as diuretic.

Name: Pistacia kinjuk Stocks
Uses: It is used in eczema and for whoop cough.

Name: Pistacia lentiscus L.
Uses: Resin carminative, diuretic, stimulant, astringent.

Name: Pistacia vera L.
Uses:
The kernel is used as a cardiac and brain tonic. Flowers are included in prescriptions for
leucorrhoea. Husk is used against dysentery and as astringent in stomatitis and tonsillitis.

Name: Pistia stratiotes L.
Uses: Leaves and root are used in dysuria, dysentery,  cough and asthma. Ash of the plant as an application for ringworm.

Name: Pisum sativum L.
Uses: Pea oil when given parenterally showed possibility of preventing pregnancy.

Name: Pithecellobium angulatum Benth.
Uses: Leaves used in poultices to swellings, and chickenpox and smallpox pustules. Ashes of the leaves mixed with coconut oil used in skin infections.

Name: Pithecellobium clypearia Benth.
Uses:
The plant is used in poultices and is applied to swellings, and chickenpox and smallpox pustules.
The leaves ashes are mixed with coconut oil and is used in skin infections.

Name: Pithecellobium dulce (Roxb.) Benth.
Uses: Hemolytic agglutinating reaction is shown with human blood while using saline extract of seeds.

Name: Pithecellobium monadelphum (Roxb.) Koster
Uses:
Leaf used externally as a mostrum for leprosy; also
applied for promoting growth of hair.

Name: Pittosporum napaulense (DC.) Rehder & E.H.Wilson
Uses: Bark used in chronic bronchitis and leprous infections. Paste prepared from root used to dropsical and rheumatic swellings.

Name: Plantago amplexicaulis Cav.
Uses: The plant is the source of brown Isubgol seeds. Seeds are astringent, used in intermittent fevers and pulmonary infections and in the form of an application in ophthalmia. Juice of the seeds is used as a refrigerant.

Name: Plantago himalaica Pilger
Uses: Leaves are bruised and applied to wounds.

Name: Plantago lanceolata L.
Collector: Reporter on Economic Products to the Government of India
Uses:
Leaves and roots astringent and vulnerary, used in cough, asthma and other pulmonary diseases. Leaves applied to
wounds and sores; extracts of young leaves showed antibacterial action. Seeds diuretic, purgative, and hemostatic.

Name: Plantago major L.
Uses: The  plant is hemostatic and  having wound-healing property in burns and inflammation of tissues. In homoeopathy it is used in disorders of epidermis and in headache, earache and toothache. Leaves are cooling, febrifuge, diuretic, astringent and vulnerary; their infusion is used in diarrhoea and piles; decoction used as an eye-wash and their ointment in skin troubles. Roots are astringent and febrifuge. Seeds are demulcent, stimulant, diuretic and als

Name: Plantago ovata Forsk.
Uses: Dried seeds and husk are used as an emollient, demulcent and laxative also used in chronic constipation, dysentery and diarrhoea, and inflammatory conditions of gastro-intestinal and genitourinary tract. Seeds are prescribed in febrile conditions and infections of kidneys, bladder, and urethra. Poultice of crushed seeds are applied to rheumatic and glandular swellings. Muscilage is present mainly in the husk.

Name: Plantago psyllium L.
Uses: Dried seeds of the plant are used as a laxative in chronic constipation.It is also useful as a demulcent and expectorant.

Name: Platanus orientalis L.
Uses:
Bark is anti-scorbutic and antirheumatic. It is boiled in vinegar and used in treating 
diarrhea and dysentery.

Name: Plectranthus mollis (Aiton) Spreng.
Uses: The leaves are crushed and are applied to stop bleeding and used as a febrifuge; also considered as a mosquito repellent. An essential oil is obtained from the leaves and flowering tops which acts as a cardiac depressant, respiratory stimulant, and vasoconstrictor; it also show relaxant activity on smooth and skeletal muscles.

Name: Pleopeltis macrocarpa (Borry ex Willd.) Kaulf.
Uses: The decoction of the plant is used for colds, sore throat and also for itching.

Name: Plesmonium margaritiferum (Roxb.) Schott
Uses: Seeds used in tootheche.

Name: Pluchea indica Less.
Uses:
Roots and leaves are antipyretic and diaphoretic. 
Leaf-juice is used in dysentery, leaf infusion in lumbago and leucorrhoea. 
Leaves are used in poultices against atonic and gangrenous ulcers.

Name: Pluchea lanceolata (DC.) C.B.Clarke
Uses: Plant used in treatment of  rheumatoid arthiritis.

Name: Plumbago indica L.
Uses:
Roots are used in  treatment of leucoderma, syphilis, leprosy, and as  vesicant, sialogogue, and abortifacient. Used as substitute  of cantharides. Root tincture used in treatment of in dyspeptic and other digestive troubles and piles. Plumbagin, which is an orange-yellow pigment, in small doses has stimulant
action on central nervous system and muscles, and in the secretion of sweat, urine, and bile.

Name: Plumbago zeylanica L.
Uses:
Root is used as  vesicant, abortifacient, and diuretic, and used in treatment of dyspepsia, piles, anasarca,
diarrhoea and skin diseases. Root paste is applied for opening abscesses. Root infusion is used in influenza and black-water fever treatment. Root bark contains plumbagin pigment.

Name: Plumeria alba L.
Uses:
Latex is applied to ulcers, herpes, and used in treatment of  scabies. Seeds are hemostatic.
Bark is stimulant and its decoction is used as a purgative, febrifuge, and emmenagogue. Bark is used in
 dropsical and venereal infections and is said to be a powerful antiherpatic. Latex is  rubefacient and 
purgative; and is used for treatment of   itch, rheumatism, and gum troubles. Roots are cathartic.

Name: Plumeria rubra L.
Uses:
Bark is stimulant and its decoction is used as a purgative, febrifuge, and emmenagogue. Bark is used in
 dropsical and venerealaffections and is said to be a powerful antiherpatic. Latex is  rubefacient and 
purgative; and is used for treatment of   itch, rheumatism, and gum troubles. Roots are cathartic.

Name: Plumeria rubra L. forma acuminata
Uses:
Bark is stimulant and its decoction is used as a purgative, febrifuge, and emmenagogue. Bark is used in
 dropsical and venereal infections and is said to be a powerful antiherpatic. Latex is  rubefacient and purgative; and is used for treatment of   itch, rheumatism,and gum troubles. Roots are cathartic.

Name: Podocarpus neriifolia D.Don
Uses: Leaf is used to treat rheumatism.

Name: Pogostemon benghalense (Burm.) Kuntze
Uses: The roots of the plant is employed as antihaemorrbagic  and stimulant. The leaves of the plant is employed as a stimulant and styptic. In colic the juice of the leaves is given and it is used as a febrifuge.

Name: Pogostemon heyneanus Benth.
Uses: The plant is used as diuretic and carminative. The leaves decoction  is prescribed  in cough and asthma, and that of the roots for dropsy.  For sternutatory powdered leaves are employed.

Name: Pogostemon parviflorus Benth.
Uses: The roots of the plant is employed as antihaemorrbagic  and stimulant. The leaves of the plant is employed as a stimulant and styptic. In colic the juice of the leaves is given and it is used as a febrifuge.

Name: Pogostemon purpurascens Dalzell
Uses: The roots of the plant is employed as antihaemorrbagic  and stimulant. The leaves of the plant is employed as a stimulant and styptic. In colic the juice of the leaves is given and it is used as a febrifuge.

Name: Polyalthia longifolia (Sonn.) Thwaites
Uses: Bark has febrifuge property.

Name: Polycarpea corymbosa (L.) Lam.
Uses: The her is useed in inflamatory swellings, urinary calculi, boils, strangury. Its Ash is mixed with pepper and applied in boils and ulcers.Pounded leaves are useful in Poultice and inflamatory swellins.

Name: Polycarpon prostratum (Forsk.) Aschers. & Schweinf.
Uses: The roasted leaves infusion prescribed  for cough following fevers, particularly after measles.

Name: Polygala crotalarioides Buch.-Ham. ex DC.
Uses: Applied for cough and pulmonary catarrh.

Name: Polygala elongata Klein ex Willd.
Uses: Decoction of leaves applied in biliousness and constipation.

Name: Polygala glomerata Lour.
Uses: The  shoots decoction is prescribed for inflammatory conditions. Infusion is used in asthma and chronic bronchitis.

Name: Polygala sibirica L.
Uses: Leaves applied in spermatorrhoea. Decoction of roots used as an expectorant in colds and coughs and also in chronic chest problems. Also applied for diarrhoea and inflammation of the urinary bladder.

Name: Polygala telephioides Willd.
Uses: Infusion of leaves used in  cure of chronic bronchitis, asthma and catarrhal infections.Roots applied for fevers and dizziness problem.

Name: Polygonatum multiflorum (L.) Allioni
Uses: Rhizomes used as tonic and demulcent; bruises, piles, inflammations, tumours, and discolouration of the skin resulting from blows.

Name: Polygonum aviculare L.
Uses: Herb astringent, tonic antipyretic, diuretic, hemostatic, and vermifuge, used in diabetes and rheumatism and for ulcers. Decoction given in diarrhoea and dysentery and to check excessive menses. Aromatic seeds emetic and cathartic.

Name: Polygonum barbatum L.
Uses: Decoction made of shoots is used to cure ulcers; juice has cicatrizing property. Used as purgative, emetic and tonic.

Name: Polygonum chinense L.
Uses: The plantis used as  antiscorbutic, tonic and vulnerary.

Name: Polygonum glabrum Willd.
Uses: Infusion of leaves given in colic and as a febrifuge. Root-stocks used for piles, jaundice, debility and consumption.

Name: Polygonum hydropiper L.
Uses: The plant is having stimulant, diuretic, styptic, emmenagogue, and lithontriptic properties. From the herb  a liquid extract is made which is used as n oral contraceptive; the infusion of the plant is employed in uterine disorders and as a hemostatic. The roots of the plant is used as  stimulant, diuretic, carminative, tonic, and anthelmintic. For skin infections the juice is used. Crushed leaves and seeds used as a vesicant like mustard poultice.

Name: Polygonum molle D.Don
Uses: The whole plant body is used as astringent, used in diarrhoea.

Name: Polygonum nepalense Meissn.
Uses: Leaves are applied to get relief from swellings.

Name: Polygonum orientale L.
Uses: Plant prescribed as a tonic and use in the healing of wounds.. Nuts used in treatment of tubercular swellings and flatulence.

Name: Polygonum persicaria L.
Uses: The plant is used as anthelmintic, carminative and diuretic.

Name: Polygonum plebeium R.Br.
Uses: The plant is prescribed in bowel complaints and pneumonia.

Name: Polygonum polystachyum Wall. ex Meissn.
Uses: A pickle is produced from the plant. No medicinal use has been found in the available literature.

Name: Polygonum tenellum Blume
Uses: The leaves decoction is used for indigestion and after parturition.

Name: Polygonum virginianum L.
Uses: Plants extract have astringent, diuretic, demulcent, vulnerary, and antispasmodic, antibacterial properties

Name: Polygonum viviparum L.
Uses:
Root stacks are used to make  tonic which is useful as astringent and used to cure dysentery, diarrhoea
and hemoptysis. Decoction prepered from the herb is used as a gargle and as for treatment of ulcers.

Name: Polypodium vulgare L.
Uses: The plant is having aperient properties.

Name: Polyscias fruticosa (L.) Harms
Uses:
Leaves and roots diuretic; their decoction given in dysuria and treatment of stone and gravel. Powdered leaves are mixed with salt and used as a
vulnerary.

Name: Populus alba L.
Uses:
Bark is tonic, diuretic,antipyretic and used as substitute for quinine. 
It is used in stranguary and skin troubles. It is used in treating intermittent fevers, rheumatism, coryza, neuralgia.

Name: Populus euphratica Oliv.
Uses: Bark is vermifuge.

Name: Portulaca oleracea L.
Uses:
Herb refrigerant, vulnerary, antiscorbutic, aperient, and diuretic. applied in scurvy; used in diseases of liver, spleen, kidney and bladder. It is also used in
cardio-vascular diseases, dysuria, haematuria, in dysentery, sore nipples, and ulceration of the mouth. In homoeopathy the herb is used to stimulate gastric secretion. Roasted seeds considered diuretic and antidysenteric; also applied in applications for burns and scalds.

Name: Portulaca pilosa L.
Uses: Used as Febrifuge, aperient, and diuretic.

Name: Portulaca quadrifida L.
Uses: Applied in asthma, coughs, urinary discharges, inflammations and ulcers.

Name: Potentilla anserina L.
Uses: Used in treatment of kidney stones, arthritis, diarrhoea, leucorrhoea, and menstrual cramps.

Name: Potentilla arbuscula D.Don
Uses: It has astringent and antispasmodic properties.

Name: Potentilla lineata Trevir ex Reich.
Uses: Roots are used in treatment of diarhhoea.

Name: Potentilla nepalensis Hook.
Uses: Root stock applied in case of burns and boils.

Name: Potentilla reptans L.
Uses: It has astringent, hemostatic, and febrifugic properties and also used in treatment of diarrhoea.

Name: Potentilla sundaica (Blume) Kuntze
Uses: It has astringent properties and fresh leaves are applied to abscesses.

Name: Potentilla supina L.
Uses: Roots have astringent, tonic and febrifugic properties.

Name: Pothos cathcartii Schott
Uses: Leaves mixed with ghee used for body pains.

Name: Pothos scandens L.
Uses: Stems are mixed with camphor and smoked for relief in asthma. Powered leaves applied to smallpox pustules.

Name: Pouzolzia sanguinea (Blume) Merr.
Uses: Plants used to prepare a medicine used in fever in Assam. Whole plants are used in eatching, mediciens prepared from stems applied in wounds.

Name: Pouzolzia zeylanica (L.) Benn.
Uses: Leaves are used as vulnerary and as  cicatrizant for gangrenous ulcers. Juice of the leaves and their decoction used as a galactagogue. Poultice of herb applied to sores and boils.

Name: Prangos pabularia Lindl.
Uses: Roots are burnt as incense by the local people. They are used as diuretic and applied also in the treatment of itches. Infusion is  given for indigestion and irregularity of menses. Roots produces an essential oil and are a good source of coumarin compounds. Fruits used as a carminative, laxative, diuretic, stimulant, liver tonic and aphrodisiac. It is said to promote expulsion of foetus.

Name: Pratia nummularia (Lam.) A.Braun & Asch.
Uses:
It is used for treatment of  dysentery and asthma; decoction is used  as  diaphoretic. Leaves are used 
for the treatment of sprue. Juice is used to coagulates blood and stops bleeding.

Name: Premna corymbosa Rottler & Willd.
Uses: Roots have laxative, stomachic, cordial, and tonic properties.Leaf decoction used in flatulence and colic.

Name: Premna divaricata Wall.
Uses: Leaves used for treating colds.

Name: Premna latifolia Roxb.
Uses: Leaves have diuretic properties and is used in treating dropsy.

Name: Premna tomentosa Willd.
Uses:
Leaves have diuretic and vulnerary properties and is used in dropsy  and given after
parturition. Bark and root extract used in stomach pain and dysentry.

Name: Primula reticulata Wall.
Uses: Plants are used externally as an anodyne, and may produce dermatitis in some individuals.

Name: Prinsepia utilis Royle
Uses: Oil extracted from the plant is used in treatment of rheumatism and fatigue.

Name: Prosopis chilensis (Molana) Stuntze
Uses: Spongy walls of ripe pods are highly nutritive; a fair source of digestible protein and of importance as a stock feed.

Name: Prosopis cineraria (L.) Druce
Uses: Flower use to prevent miscarriage. Pod astringent, pectoral, demulcent. Bark antiinflammatory, antirheumatic.

Name: Prunella vulgaris L.
Uses: It has Expectorant and antispasmodic properties.

Name: Prunus armeniaca L.
Uses: Oil extracted from seeds is utilised in pharmaceutical industry.

Name: Prunus avium L.
Uses: Stems yield a non toxic extract used in cardiac problems.

Name: Prunus cerasoides D.Don
Uses: Kernel yields a medicinal oil.

Name: Prunus cerasus L.
Uses: Bark extraxt used in relieving heart palpitation, diarrhoea and as a febrifuge.  Leaf infusion is used to cure convulsions in children.

Name: Prunus ceylanica (Wight) Miq.
Uses: Bark used in treating stomach ache.

Name: Prunus domestica L.
Uses: It has demulcent, laxative, and refrigerant properties, and used as a constituent of cathartic decoctions.

Name: Prunus dulcis (Mill.) D.A.Webb.
Uses: Kernels are used in treatment of peptic ulcers. Unripe fruits usually applied as an astringent in gums and mouth.

Name: Prunus mahaleb L.
Uses: A medicinal oil is obtained from seeds.

Name: Prunus persica (L.) Batsch
Uses: Leaf and bark infusion is used for treatment of whooping cough and  flowers are anthelmintic.

Name: Prunus salicina Lindl.
Uses: Fruit extract used in treatment of arthiritis.

Name: Prunus undulata Buch.-Ham. ex D.Don
Uses: Leaf is used in medicines employed to kill maggots.

Name: Psammogeton canescens (DC.) Vatke
Uses: Plants are used as a stomachic

Name: Pseudarthria viscida (L.) Wight & Arn.
Uses:
Root astringent, febrifuge,
antirheumatic. A decoction or
powder is used for biliousness
and diarrhoea.

Name: Psidium guajava L.
Uses: Leaves used as an astringent for bowel troubles and decoction of bark used in treatment of diarrhoea. Fruits tonic, cooling, and laxative properties useful in colic and bleeding gums.

Name: Psoralea corylifolia L.
Uses:
Seed used in leucoderma,
vitiligo, leprosy, psoriasis and
inflammatory diseases of the skin, both orally and externally.

Name: Pteridium aquilinum (L.) Kuhn.
Uses: The decoction of fresh fronds are recommended for dysentery.  The juice of rhizomes is applied to the glandular swellings of the neck.

Name: Pterocarpus indicus Willd.
Uses: Pounded leaves used as a sternutatory.Decoction given in dropsy and stone in the bladder. Bark yields a kino, applied to sores; also used for thrush and diarrhoea. Seeds emetic.

Name: Pterocarpus marsupium Roxb.
Uses:
Yields a kino used in diarrhoea and dysentery. Aqueous extract of wood given to diabetics. Aqueous infusion of wood used in diabetes and water stored
in vessels made of this wood is reputed for its antidiabetic qualities.

Name: Pterocarpus santalinus L.f.
Uses: Wood use as tonic and diaphoretic, paste applied to inflammations and to forehead in headache. Decoction of fruits used in chronic dysentery.

Name: Pterocymbium javanicum R.Br.
Uses: The gm resembles tragacanth.

Name: Pterospermum acerifolium (L.) Willd.
Uses: Flowers useful for leprosy, inflammations, ulcers and tumours.

Name: Pterospermum suberifolium Lam.
Uses: Flowers are useful in curing bronchites, throat complaints, skin disease, leprosy, headache, inflamations, sores, biliousness. A paste is made from the flower with rice water forms an application for hemicrania.

Name: Pterospermum xylocarpum (Gaertn.) Oken
Collector: N. Rama Rao and D. Narsimhan
Uses: Leaves  used in leucorrhoea.

Name: Pueraria phaseoloides (Roxb.) Benth.
Uses:
The plant is used against ulcers
and boils.

Name: Pueraria tuberosa (Roxb. ex Willd.) DC.
Uses:
Tuber use as diuretic, cardiac
tonic, galactagogue. Also used forfertility control. Root used as a demulcent, and refrigerant in fevers, as cataplasm for swelling of joints, as galactagogue.

Name: Pulicaria crispa (Forssk.) Benth.
Uses: Dried herb is  used as a vulnerary for bruises and sores. Decoction is used as  febrifuge.

Name: Pulicaria dysenterica (L.) Gaeertn.
Uses: It is astringent and diuretic. It is used in treatment of  diarrhoea and dysentery.

Name: Punica granatum L.
Uses: Fruit is used in cholera, dysentery, diarrhoea.

Name: Quercus infectoria Oliv.
Uses: Bark has astringent properties, which is used in treatment ofintertrigo, impetigo, and eczema.

Name: Quercus lamellosa Sm.
Uses: Bark extract used as an astringent.

Name: Quercus leucotrichophora A.Camus ex Bahadur
Uses: Acorns are used in treatment of gonorrhoea and diarhhoea.

Name: Quercus pachyphylla Kurz
Uses: Bark and acorns have astringent properties.

Name: Quisqualis indica L.
Uses: Fruits and seeds have anthelmintic and soporific properties. Seeds also used in diarrhoea and rickets and parasitic skin troubles and has purgative action

Name: Radermachera xylocarpa (Roxb.) K.Schum.
Uses: Resin extracted from wood is used to treat skin troubles.

Name: Randia cochinchinensis (Lour.) Merr.
Uses: Decoction of roots are used for treating bowel complaints.

Name: Randia longiflora Lam.
Uses: Berries are used for medicinal purpose.

Name: Randia tomentosa Hook.f.
Uses:
They are emetic and used as a substitute for Ipecacuanha (Cephaelis ipecacuanha A. Rich.).
 In small doses, it is  expectorant and diaphoretic.  Bark is astringent .Bark is given in treatment of 
diarrhea and dysentery.Infusion is used as an emetic. Bark is a sedative and is used to relieve pains due 
to bruises, and bone-ache during fever. It is also given internally and used externally as an anodyne in 
treatment of  rheumatism.

Name: Ranunculus aquatilis L.
Uses: Used in treating asthma, intermittent fevers and rheumatism.

Name: Ranunculus arvensis L.
Uses: Useful in gout, intermittent fevers,  asthma,have antibiotic activity; active principles protoanemonin and ranunculin have been isolatedfrom it.

Name: Ranunculus cantoniensis DC.
Uses: Applied as a vesicant. Posesantibacterial activity.

Name: Ranunculus lingua L.
Uses: Leaves applied as a vesicant in rheumatism of the joints. Herb causes irritation of the mucous membrane and inflammation of intestinal tract in livestock; the toxicity, however, is lost on drying. Protoanemonine is the toxic principle.

Name: Ranunculus muricatus L.
Uses: Useful in gout, intermittent fever and asthma.

Name: Ranunculus sceleratus L.
Uses: Plant used as stimulant and diuretic. Juice useful in sciatica, rheumatism, dysuria, asthma, pneumonia and gripe. Drug used as  vermifuge and in cutaneous disorders. Seeds prescribed as a tonic and stomachic also used in kidney troubles.

Name: Raphanus sativus L.
Collector: Reporter on Economic Products to the Government of India
Uses: Roots applied as a diuretic in urinary troubles, piles, and gastrodynia. Juice of fresh leaves diuretic and laxative. Seeds expectorant, diuretic, and carminative.

Name: Rauvolfia sarpentina (L.) Benth. ex Kurz
Uses: Roots constitute the drug Rauvolfia which is used for the treatment of  nervous disorders including anxiety states, excitement, maniacal behaviour associated with psychosis, schizophrenia, insanity, insomnia, and epilepsy. Extracts of the roots is used  for intestinal troubles. Roots are used to stimulate uterine contraction and in cases of difficult delivery. Juice of the leaves are used  for clearing the torneal  opacity. Rauvolfia and its preparati

Name: Rauvolfia tetraphylla L.
Uses: Extract of the herb is  mixed with castor oil  and is applied to treat skin ailments.

Name: Reinwardtia indica Dumort.
Uses: Used in treating paralysis. It is also used for the treatment of founder disease of cattle. Crushed leaves and stems are given to maggot infested wounds.

Name: Reissantia indica (Willd.) Halle
Uses: Root bark used for the treatment of respiratory troubles. Stem febrifuge. Leaves scorched and given to women during confinement. Powdered leaves and roots are applied to sores and wounds.

Name: Remusatia vivipara (Roxb.) Schott
Uses: The ointment made from roots and turmeric used in itching. Juice alexipharmac.

Name: Reseda odorata L.
Uses: Roots useful as a laxative, diuretic, diaphoretic. Seeds applied externally as a resolvent

Name: Rhamnus nepalensis (Wall.) M.A.Lawson
Uses: The fruit  is used for treatment of herpes.

Name: Rhamnus purpureus Edgew.
Uses: Fruit is used as a purgative.

Name: Rhamnus triquetra Wall. ex Roxb.
Uses: The bark is used as a tonic, astringent and deobstruent.

Name: Rhamnus virgatus Roxb.
Uses: Fruit emetic and purgative, used in spleen infections.

Name: Rhamnus wightii Wight & Arn.
Uses: Bark use as tonic, astringent, and deobstruent.

Name: Rheum emodi Wall. ex Meissn.
Uses: Dried rhizomes and roots are useful as a purgative and astringent tonic; its stimulating effect combined with aperient properties renders it especially useful in a tonic dyspepsia. Its use is prohibited for patients suffering from gout, rheumatism, epilepsy, and uric acid troubles. Powdered roots used for cleaning teeth, also sprinkled over ulcers. Leaf stalks have a purgative action.

Name: Rheum spiciforme Royle
Uses: Roots are purgative.

Name: Rheum webbianum Royle
Uses: Rhizomes are bitter, astringent and purgative.

Name: Rhinacanthus nasuta (L.) Kurz
Uses: Fresh leaves used against eczema, ringworm and cancer.

Name: Rhizophora mucronata Lam.
Uses:
Bark is  astringent and is  used in  treatment of hemorrhages, hematuria and angina. It is also used for
 treatment of diabetes.

Name: Rhodamnia trinervia Blume
Uses: Root and leaf decoction is used after parturition. Shoots are applied to scalds. Fruit decoction is used in case of gum troubles

Name: Rhododendron anthopogon D.Don
Uses: Yields an incense. Leaves are stimulant.

Name: Rhododendron arboreum Sm.
Uses: A sub-acidic jelly or preserve is made from the petals also used in diarrhoea and dysentery.

Name: Rhododendron campanulatum D.Don
Uses: Leaves are used in chronic rheumatism, syphilis and sciatica. They are mixed  with tobacco and used as snuff to cure bemicrania and colds.

Name: Rhododendron lepidotum Wall. ex G.Don
Uses: Leaves are used as stimulant.

Name: Rhododendron setosum D.Don
Uses: Leaves are used as stimulant.

Name: Rhodomyrtus tomentosa Wight
Uses: Fruits given in diarrhoea and dysentery. Root decoction prescribed for diarrhoea and stomach-ache.

Name: Rhus coriaria L.
Uses: Leaves and seeds astringent, styptic.

Name: Rhus hookeri K.C.Sahni & Bahadur
Uses: Galls on the branch are astringent, tonic, expectorant, and stimulant, used in diarrhoea and dysentery. Extract of leaves shows anti-cancer and anti-viral action. Juice powerful vesicant; also used in colic.

Name: Rhus javanica L.
Uses:
Galls used in ointments and suppositories employed in
the treatment of haemorrhoids,
swellings and wounds. Fruits
used for colic, diarrhoea and dysentery.

Name: Rhus parviflora Roxb. ex DC.
Uses:
The root bark is used for irritable bladder, bed-wetting
and urinary incontinence.

Name: Rhus punjabensis J.L.Stew. ex Brand.
Uses: Leaves contain tannin. Juice from the tree is a vesicant.

Name: Rhus succedanea L.
Uses: Thorn-like excrescences on the branches used in diarrhoea, dysentery and vomiting. Fruits used as an adjuvant in tuberculosis.

Name: Rhynchosia minima (L.) DC.
Uses:
Leaves used as an abortifacient. Toxic to fish. Seeds poisonous, extract shows specific agglutinating activity with
certain types of red blood cells.

Name: Rhynchostylis retusa (L.) Blume
Uses: Used as an skin emollient.

Name: Ribes alpestre Wall. ex Decne.
Uses: Branches are Used as symbol in religious rites. No medicinal use has been found in the available literature.

Name: Ribes orientalis Desf.
Uses: Fruits are purgative in nature.

Name: Ricinus communis L.
Uses: The poultice of leaves are applied for boils and sores. The decoction of roots is prescribed for lumbago.

Name: Rivea ornata (Roxb.) Choisy.
Uses: Juice used in piles and phthiriasis treatment

Name: Rorippa indica (L.) Hiern
Uses: Herb diuretic stimulant and antiscorbutic. Useful in diarrhoea, dysentery and fevers. Seeds applied as laxative, used in asthma.

Name: Rorippa islandica (Oeder) Borbás
Uses: Herb antiscorbutic, tonic,stimulant, diuretic, deobstruent, hepatic and stomachic.

Name: Rorippa nasturtium-aquaticum (L.) Hayek
Uses: Herb diuretic stimulant and antiscorbutic. Useful in diarrhoea, dysentery and fevers. Seeds applied as laxative, used in asthma.

Name: Rosa banksiae R.Br.
Uses: Root is used as a tonic and has anthelmintic properties.

Name: Rosa brunonii Lindl.
Uses: Root used in treatment of eye infections.

Name: Rosa centifolia L.
Uses: Flower decoction used in treatment of ulcers, haemorrhages and diarrhoea

Name: Rosa damascena Mill.
Uses: Tonic obtained from flowers are used in cardiac troubles and enlarged tonsils.

Name: Rosa multiflora Thunb.
Uses: Fruits are cathartic and used for treatment of ulcers.

Name: Roscoea purpurea Sm.
Uses: Dried leaves and flower-buds are used in medicine.

Name: Rosmarinus officinalis L.
Uses: It has carminative properties and acts as a cardiac stimulant.

Name: Rotula aquatica Lour.
Uses:
Decoction of roots are used as diuretic and laxative and used for treatment of piles,
stones in bladder and venereal diseases.

Name: Roylea cineria (D.Don) Baill.
Collector: O. Polunin, W.R. Sykes and L.H.J. Williams
Uses: The plant produces a medicine used for purification of blood, fever, pimples.

Name: Rubia cordifolia L.
Uses: Root extract are antidysenteric and antiseptic in nature. Leaf and stem decoction is used as vermifuge and is also a constituent of the drug septilin, which is used for rhinosinal infections.

Name: Rubia tinctorum L.
Uses:
Roots are astringent, tonic, diuretic, and lithontriptic. It is  used  in treatment of  diseases of liver, 
gall bladder ,spleen ,arthritis and bed sores.

Name: Rubus moluccanus L.
Uses: Fruit juice used in treatment of fistula.

Name: Rumex acetosa L.
Uses: Herb has antiscorbutic property (vitamin C 124 mg/100 g). It is also useful in bronchial diseases and in homoeopathy for skin related troubles and convulsions. Leaves are used as refrigerant and diuretic. Leaves are used for cutaneous tumours. Infusions of roots are used as a diuretic and for skin troubles. Root powder used in diarrhoea.

Name: Rumex acetosella L.
Uses: Leaves are useful in cancer and other tumours. Fresh plant juice is refrigerant, diaphoretic, diuretic, and antiscorbutic. Total ascorbic acid content of leaves varies from 750-1200 mg/100 g on dry weight basis. Young leaves contain maximum amount of ascorbic acid and the free ascorbic acid content (50-150 mg/lOOg) remains constant throughout the year.

Name: Rumex crispus L.
Uses: Root is purgative. Seeds are applied in diarrhoea.

Name: Rumex dentatus L.
Uses: Leaves are rich source of calcium (612 mg/100 g),p- carotene, vitamin A (11,700 I. U./I00 g), and vitamin C (115 mg/ 100 g). Roots used in cutaneous disorders

Name: Rumex maritimus L.
Uses: Plants are used as refrigerant,  also used as antipruritic. Leaves are cathartic, also applied to urns.

Name: Rumex nepalensis Spreng.
Uses: Infusion of leaves are given in colic and given to syphilitic ulcers; strong decoction useful for bilharziasis. Leaves give relief from irritation caused by stinging nettle.

Name: Rumex scutatus L.
Uses: Leaf juice is an antiscorbutic. Herb is refrigerant and astringent, given in dysentery.

Name: Rungia parviflora (Retz.) Nees
Uses: Pounded leaves is applied in contusions and Roots have febrifugic properties.

Name: Rungia repens (L.) Nees
Uses: Dried herb used in treating cough and cold and fresh pounded leaves applied to scalp infections.

Name: Ruta graveolens L.
Uses: It has anthelmintic, antispasmodic, antiepileptic, rubefacient, and emmenagoguic properties.

Name: Saccharum bengalense Retz.
Uses: Roots used in dysentery, strangury, boils, eye diseases etc.

Name: Saccharum spontaneum L.
Uses: Root is used as a galactagogue and diuretic.

Name: Sageraea laurifolia (Grah.) Blatter
Uses: Leaves used for treating rheumatism.

Name: Sagittaria sagittifolia L.
Uses: Tubers used for cutaneous troubles. Leaves powder used for relief from itch, sore throat and inflammation of the breast.

Name: Salacia chinensis L.
Uses:
Roots used in diabetes. Also used for amenorrhoea,
dysmenorrhoea and genito-urinary and venereal diseases.

Name: Salacia oblonga Wall.
Uses:
Root bark used for the treatment rheumatism; also for
gonorrhoea, swellings and skin
diseases. Plant mildly antiseptic.

Name: Salacia reticulata Wight
Uses: Plant mild antiseptic. Root bark used against gonorrhoea, skin diseases and inflammations. The root bark exhibits hypoglycaemic activity.

Name: Salicornia brachiata Roxb.
Uses: The whole plant produces a medicine used for abortion.

Name: Salix acmophylla Boiss.
Uses: Decoction of bark is used as febrifuge.

Name: Salix babylonica L.
Uses: Catkins and young twigs are used as an antipyretic. Infusion of leaves are used in treating rheumatism.

Name: Salix caprea L.
Uses:
Decoction of leaves are used as febrifuge. Bark and twigs are used in astringent
 applications for piles. Ashes of wood in hemoptysis and mixed with vinegar and applied to piles.

Name: Salix tetrasperma Roxb.
Uses: Dried leaves are mixed with sugar and are given for rheumatism, epilepsy, venereal diseases, stones in bladder, piles, swellings. Bark is used as febrifuge.

Name: Salsola baryosma (R.& S.) Dandy
Uses: Ashes of the plant are applied in itching.

Name: Salsola kali L.
Uses: Plant is anthelmintic, diuretic, emmenagogue  and cathartic.

Name: Salvadora oleoides Decne.
Uses:
Leaves are used for relief in cough. 
Fruits are used for enlarged spleen ,low fever, and rheumatism. 
Root-bark is used as a vesicant. 
It is also used for rheumatic pains and in suppositories, and forms an ointment base.

Name: Salvadora persica L.
Uses: The decoction of roots is used as a tonic and emmenagogue. Stem and bark is used for gastric troubles and as an ascarifuge.The decoction of leaves used in cough and asthma, their poultice used for treatment of piles and tumours. Fruits are lithontriptic, diuretic, deobstruent,carminative, and stomachic and are used in biliousness and rheumatism.  A fatty oil applied on rheumatic swellings is obtained from the seeds.

Name: Salvia aegyptica L.
Uses: Seeds are used for treating diarrhoea and hemorrhoids.

Name: Salvia moorcroftiana Wall. ex Benth.
Uses: Leaves applied to boils, wounds, and chronic skin infections. Seeds are employed in colic, dysentery, and hemorrhoids.

Name: Salvia officinalis L.
Uses: Used in treating gynocological problem.

Name: Salvia plebeia R.Br.
Uses: Used in treating menorrhagia,diarrhoea, and hemorrhoids

Name: Samadera indica Gaertn.
Uses: Bark juice used in treating skin infections.

Name: Sambucus nigra L.
Uses: Leaf decoction has laxative, diuretic, and diaphoretic properties. Roots are emetic and diuretic. Fruit extract is used in treatment of  colds, inflamed throat, gout, rheumatism, and neuralgia.

Name: Sambucus wightiana Wall. ex Wight & Arn.
Scientific Name: Sambucus wightiana Wall. ex Wight & Arn.
Uses:
The roots, berries and leaves of the plant is used as a purgative and in dropsy.
Root or inner bark decoction is an effective diuretic. Leaves are diaphoretic, expectorant,  and diuretic.

Name: Sandoricum indicum Cav.
Uses: Roots used in treating diarrhoea and dysentery.

Name: Santaloides minus Schellenb.
Uses: Roots and twigs used as a bitter tonic and for rheumatism, scurvy, pulmonary complaints, and diabetes; also used as a mild aperient and in external applications for ulcers and skin troubles.

Name: Santalum album L.
Uses: Both the wood and oil are diuretic, diaphoretic, and expectorant.

Name: Sapindus mukorossi Gaertn.
Uses: Fruits emetic and expectorant; used in excessive salivation, chlorosis and epilepsy.

Name: Sapindus trifoliatus L.
Uses: Fruit Pulp aqueous solution used as nasal drops in migraine, epilepsy and hysteria. Root used for gout, rheumatism and paralysis.

Name: Sapium indicum Willd.
Uses: The  root-bark decotion is considered of having emetic and purgative properties  and it is also utilized in hydrophobia and insanity.

Name: Sapium insigne (Royle) Benth.
Uses: The milky juice of the plant is having acrid and vesicant qualities.

Name: Sapium sebiferum (L.) Roxb.
Uses: The oil is considered of having vulnerary, emetic and purgative properties and is utilized for cutaneous problems. The root bark decotion is prescibed  in dyspepsia also used as a tonic. The  resin obtained from the bark is having purgative properties.

Name: Saprosma ternatum Benth. & Hook.f.
Uses: Leaves are useful for relieving stomach pain and flatulance.

Name: Saraca indica L.
Uses: Flowers use as pounded and mixed with water, used in haemorrhagic dysentery, bleeding piles and retention of urine.

Name: Sarcococca saligna Muell.Arg.
Uses: Leaves of the plant is utilized for rheumatism and as febrifuge.

Name: Sarcostemma acidum (Roxb.) Voigt.
Uses: Dried stems  are emetic. Infusion of roots is given to persons bitten by rabid dogs.

Name: Sarcostemma brunonianum Wight & Arn.
Uses: Dried stems  are emetic. Infusion of roots is given to persons bitten by rabid dogs.

Name: Sarcostemma intermedium Decne.
Uses: Dried stems  are emetic. Infusion of roots is given to persons bitten by rabid dogs.

Name: Sarcostigma kleinii Wight & Arn.
Uses: Fruits used in rheumatism and bark in leprosy and hysteria.

Name: Satureja hortensis L.
Uses: The plant is having carminative, digestive, diuretic, laxative, stomachic, sudorific, and vermifuge properties. It is employed in menstrual suppression and flatulent colic. A tea prepared from the leaves is given as an expectorant and carminative. An essential oil- Oil of Savory is obtained from the herb which is used for the same purposes as the herb which possesses antibacterial and antifungal activity

Name: Sauromatum venosum (Aiton) Kunth
Uses: Tubers used as  stimulating poultice.

Name: Sauropus androgynus (L.) Merr.
Uses: Plant is known for its high vitamin content and called Multivitamin Green. Decoction of roots given in stricture of the bladder and in fevers

Name: Sauropus quadrangularis (Willd.) Müll.Arg.
Uses: For the cure of tonsillitis the  smoke of dried leaves are utilized.

Name: Saussurea affinis Spreng. ex DC.
Uses: Juice of the roots are a common ingredient of medicines used for female troubles.

Name: Saussurea auriculata (Spreng. ex DC.) Sch.Bip.
Uses: Leaves are purgative and antisyphilitic.

Name: Saussurea heteromalla (D.Don) Hand.-Mazz.
Uses: Seeds are used as a carminative. Crushed leaves are applied to wounds

Name: Saussurea lappa (Decne.) Sch.Bip.
Uses:
Roots are tonic, stomachic, carminative, and stimulant. It is used as a spasmodic in asthma and cough, and in treating  rheumatism
and chronic skin diseases.  Alcoholic extract of roots, containing both the essential oil and alkaloid, has been found effective in bronchial
asthma particularly of vagotonic type.

Name: Saussurea obvallata (DC.) Sch.Bip.
Uses: Roots are used in preparations applied to wounds and cuts.

Name: Scaevola taccada (Gaertn.) Roxb.
Uses:
Leaves are used in treating indigestion, tumours and swollen legs. Fruits used
for eye troubles, inducing menstruation. Root decoction used in dysentery.

Name: Schima wallichii (DC.) Korth.
Uses: Plant is used as anthelmintic and rubefacient

Name: Schleichera oleosa (Lour.) Oken
Uses: Seed oil used for massage in rheumatism and applied in alopecia, itch and acne; stimulates hair growth.

Name: Schrebera swietenioides Roxb.
Uses:
Leaves are used in treatment of spleen enlargement and urinary discharges. Roots are 
used in treatment of leprosy and bark in treatment of boils.

Name: Schweinfurthia papilionacea (Burm.f.) Boiss.
Uses: Used in controlling fevers and has diuretic properties.

Name: Scilla hyacinthina (Roth) Macbridge
Uses: Used as an expectorant, diuretic and cardiac stimulant.

Name: Scindapsus officinalis (Roxb.) Schott
Uses: Fruits stimulant, diaphoretic, carminative and anthelmintic, diarrhoea, asthma. Fruits as well as shoots show hypoglycaemic activity and the former also show antiprotozoal activity.

Name: Scirpus articulatus L.
Uses: Tubers given to stop diarrhoea and vomiting.

Name: Scirpus grossus L.f.
Uses: Tubers are nutritious, diuretic, and astringent, used in diarrhoea and to stop vomiting.

Name: Scirpus lacustris L.
Uses: Rhizomes used as astringent and diuretic and suspected of poisoning cattle.

Name: Scirpus maritimus L.
Uses: Tubers used as laxative.

Name: Scleria levis Retz.
Uses: Fruits useful in coughs. Rhizome used for stomach disorders.

Name: Scleria lithosperma (L.) Sw.
Uses: Plant antinephritic. Young tops given to children with enlarged stomach. Decoction of roots given after parturition.

Name: Scoparia dulcis L.
Uses: The leaves infusion is employed in bronchitis, cough and feve and also prepared gargle for toothache.The plant  decoction is utilized for gravel and other renal troubles. From the leaves stems of green plants amellin-an antidiabetic compound is obtained which is beneficial in anaemia, albuminaria, ketonuria, retinitis, and other problems related with diabetes mellitus.

Name: Scutellaria discolor Wall. ex Benth.
Uses: Employed in rheumatism.

Name: Scutellaria galericulata L.
Uses: It has laxative, febrifuge, antispasmodic, nervine, anodyne, and stomachic properties and is employed in epilepsy, intermittent fever, and ague.

Name: Sebastiania chamaelea(L.) Muell.Arg.
Uses: The decoction of the plant is prescribed  with ghee as a tonic. It is also applied to head in vertigo. The juice  of the plant is employed in diarrhoea.

Name: Secamone emetica (Retz.) R.Br. ex Sm.
Uses: Roots are acrid, emetic.

Name: Securinega leucopyrus (Willd.) Müll.Arg.
Uses: The leaves juice or its paste is utilized along with tobacco to kill worms in the sores.

Name: Securinega virosa (Roxb. ex Willd.) Baill.
Uses: The roots of the plant is having analgesic and aphrodisiac properties. The juice of the leaf is used for killing the worms in the sores. The decoction of leaves is given as a laxative and antipyretic.

Name: Sedum multicaule Wall. ex Lindl.
Uses: It is emollient and vulnerary.

Name: Semecarpus anacardium L.f.
Uses:
Toxic drug, used only after
curing. Fruit used in rheumatoid arthritis and for the treatment of tumours and malignant growths.

Name: Senecio bhutanicus N.P.Balakr.
Uses: Seeds are used for colic.

Name: Senecio chrysanthemoides DC.
Uses:
Flowers are crushed and applied on wounds as an antiseptic. Root powder is used against rheumatic
 pain. Infusion of roots is used in treating indigestion. Plant is used as poultice, ointment/lotion is applied 
to relieve pain and inflammation.The lotion is a good pain reliever of rheumatism,rheumatoid arthritis and neuralgic pain such as sciatica.

Name: Senecio jacquemontianus (Decne.) Benth. ex Hook.f.
Uses: Root is used as a nervine tonic and for cutaneous troubles.

Name: Senecio tenuifolius Burm.f.
Uses: Leaves are emollient and vulnerary.

Name: Senecio vulgaris L.
Uses:
It is used in treatment of dysmenorrhoea and amenorrhoea and also act as a
 diaphoretic, diuretic, and tonic. Infusion is used as a lotion in chronic mastitis,
 hemorrhoids, and gout. Its extract is  given in colic and as a vermifuge. 
Decoction is purgative and emetic.

Name: Sesamum orientale L.
Uses:
Fresh leaves are used in treating infections of kidneys and Bladder. It is applied externally 
applied to cure ophthalmic and cutaneous complaints.It is emollient, lactagogue, and diuretic.

Name: Sesbania bispinosa (Jacq.) W.Wight
Uses: Plant used for treating wounds. Seeds used externally in ringworm and skin diseases.

Name: Sesbania grandiflora (L.) Poir.
Uses:
Plant astringent, antihistaminic,
febrifuge. Used for intermittent fevers, catarrh, cough, consumption, glandular enlargement.

Name: Sesbania sesban (L.) Merr.
Uses:
Leaves antiinflammatory. Bark juice applied to cutaneous eruptions. Unsaponifiable
matter of fixed oil from seeds
cardiac depressant, antibacterial. Seed and bark  used in menorrhagia, spleen enlargement and diarrhoea.

Name: Seseli diffusum (Roxb. ex Sm.) Santapau & Wagh
Scientific Name: Seseli diffusum (Roxb. ex Sm.) Santapau & Wagh
Uses: Plants are used for mental disorders. Roots used as well as aerial parts yield volatile oils. Volatile oil obtained from aerial parts causes a fall in blood pressure, vasoconstriction aud stimulation of respiration.

Name: Seseli sibiricum Benth. ex C.B.Clarke
Uses: Plants are used for mental disorders. Roots are used as well as aerial parts yield volatile oils. Volatile oil obtained from aerial parts causes a fall in blood pressure, vasoconstriction aud stimulation of respiration.

Name: Setaria plicata (Lam.) T.Cook
Uses: Leaves used in menstruation.

Name: Shorea robusta Gaertn.f.
Uses: Useful as an astringent in diarrhoea and dysentery.

Name: Sida acuta Burm.f.
Uses: Leaves are demulcent and diuretic.Leaves boiled in oil and applied to testicular swellings and in elephantiasis. In Africa, used as an abortifacient. Decoction o f leaves and roots emollient, used for hemorrhoids and impotence. Roots used as tonic, stomachic, diaphoretic, and antipyretic,used in nervous and urinary disorders and bowel complaints;

Name: Sida cordata (Burm.f.) Borss.Waalk.
Uses: Plant produces a medicine used in asthma, bone fracture, cuts and wounds.

Name: Sida cordifolia L.
Uses: Plants produces tonic and  emollient, astrigent, aphrodisiac mediciens. Removes "vata" and "Pitta". Good in cough as pectoral and bechic. Bark use ful in discharging urinary troubles and discharges. The bark of the root with sesamum oil and milk is very effective in curing facial paralysis  and sciatia caused by inflamation of nerve.

Name: Sida ovata Forsk.
Uses: Powdered seeds are mixed with jaggery and given in lumbago.

Name: Sida rhombifolia L.
Uses: Used in rheumatism and tuberculosis. Stem abounds in mucilage and used as a demulcent and emollient; used also for skin troubles and as a diuretic and febrifuge.

Name: Siegesbeckia orientalis L.
Uses:
It  possess healing properties in treating gangrenous ulcers and sores. 
Tincture of plant is used externally with glycerine to cure ringworm and other parasitic infections. Herb is considered diaphoretic, cardiotonic, antiscorbutic, and sialagogue and  used in treating  rheumatism and renal colic.

Name: Silene conoidea L.
Uses: It is used as emollient. Juice applied in ophthalmia.

Name: Silene gallica L.
Uses: It is used as emollient. Juice applied in ophthalmia.

Name: Silybum marianum (L.) Gaertn.
Uses:
It is used in jaundice and treatment of other biliary infections; intermittent fevers, dropsy, 
and uterine trouble.It is also a reliable galactagogue. Decoction is used as an application for cancer. Leaves are aperient and sudorific. Seeds are used in treatment of  jaundice, calculi of liver and gallbladder, and hemorrhages. Young leaves  are consumed for treatment of  diabetics.

Name: Sisymbrium altissimum L.
Uses: Leaves and flowers astringent and antiscorbutic.

Name: Sisymbrium irio L.
Uses: Seeds expectorant, febrifuge,and rubefacient, used in asthma, and employed in the preparation o f stimulatingpoultices.

Name: Sisymbrium loeselii L.
Uses: Seeds useful in scurvy and scrofula.

Name: Skimmia laureola (DC.) Sieb. & Zucc. ex Walp.
Scientific Name: Skimmia laureola (DC.) Sieb. & Zucc. ex Walp.
Uses: Yield a medicinal oil.

Name: Smilax glabra Roxb.
Uses: Tuberous root is used for sores and syphilis.

Name: Smilax lanceaefolia Roxb.
Uses: Tuberous rhizome is used in rheumatism and sores.

Name: Smilax ovalifolia Roxb.
Uses: Used as an alterative in syphilis, scrofula etc.

Name: Smithia conferta Sm.
Uses:
Herb laxative and tonic, used in biliousness and rheumatism; also given to women to cure
sterility.

Name: Smithia sensitiva Aiton
Uses: Herb boiled and given for gravel and difficulty in micturition.

Name: Solanum albicaule Kotschy ex Dunal
Uses: Decoction of leaves are used for ulcers.

Name: Solanum dulcamara L.
Uses:
It is used for tumours and warts, chronic rheumatism and skin infections. Infusion of dried branches are credited with sedative
and analgesic properties

Name: Solanum erianthum D.Don
Uses:
Decoction of roots are used for body pains, vertigo and urinary troubles. 
Leaves are applied during  vaginal discharges.

Name: Solanum ferox L.
Uses:
It is employed for sore-throat, cough, asthma, pain in the chest, dropsy and rheumatism. Decoction is given as an antipyretic.
Decoction of roots are given as a digestive and to relieve labour pain. Seeds and roots given to improve appetite.

Name: Solanum gracilipes Decne.
Uses: Fruits are used in otitis.

Name: Solanum indicum L.
Uses:
Roots  are carminative and expectorant. It is  useful in treating coughs and catarrhal infections, dysuria, and colic. It is pounded and
applied to nasal ulcers. Also an ingredient of Dasamula, an important Ayurvedic medicine

Name: Solanum melongena L.
Uses: Roots juice employed for otitis and nose ulcers. Leaves are used in bronchitis, asthma, and dysuria and liver complaints.

Name: Solanum nigrum L.
Uses:
It is antiseptic and antidysenteric, used in cardalgia and gripe. Infusion of  herb is  applied to anthrax pustules. The herb is  also
used as a diuretic and laxative; decoction  is  narcotic and antispasmodic. Freshly prepared extract of herb is effective in cirrhosis  of liver. Juice of  fresh leaves produces dilatation of  the pupils. Berries are  tonic, diuretic and cathartic and used in anasarca and heart diseases. They are
employed as a domestic

Name: Solanum spirale Roxb.
Uses: Roots are diuretic.

Name: Solanum surattense Burm.f.
Uses: Roots are expectorant and form a constituent of the well-known Ayurvedic preparation Dasamula. They are employed  in treaing cough,asthma, and pain in the chest.
